awd_abstract_narration:
It is now a well-established fact that nucleons, protons and neutrons, are made up of more elementary particles called quarks. The main physics program supported by this award is to measure the quark structure of light particles called mesons.  The proposed research will support the research infrastructure by commissioning new equipment to produce linearly a beam of high-energy photons from scattered electrons produced by the accelerator at the Thomas Jefferson National Accelerator Facility (Jefferson Lab).  The research will also include computer simulations of the particle detector in Hall D at Jefferson Lab.  Participation of students in the research effort is a central component of this program.

The experimental program proposed here embodies one of Jefferson Lab's priorities: to elucidate the underlying structure of protons, neutrons, and mesons. The particles of interest here are called hybrid mesons, which are identified as having quantum numbers not allowed in the constituent quark model, due to extra degrees of freedom provided by gluons, which are the force-carriers of the strong force.  The discovery of hybrid mesons would be a triumph of modern theoretical models based on the theory of quantum chromodynamics (QCD). This award will also provide support for personnel to commission the linearly polarized photon beam and the electron tagger as part of the GlueX experiment In Hall D of Jefferson Lab.

por.por_cntn:
The GlueX experiment uses an intense beam of high energy gamma rays scattered from protons in a liquid hydrogen target to study how the strong nuclear force binds quarks inside compact clusters called hadrons. It is known that all hadrons have roughly the same radius, but the exact origin of that length scale is not fully understood, nor the full set of rules that govern their relative stability. Located in experimental Hall D at Jefferson Lab in Newport News, Virginia, GlueX addresses these questions using high energy gamma rays to produce large numbers of hadrons of all possible types, with the goal of mapping the hadron mass spectrum and searching for new hadrons that violate the conventional rules established for their stability.

Figure 1 shows a floor plan of the hall where the photon beam is created. The electron beam from the Jefferson Lab accelerator enters from the left at 12 GeV energy and passes through a thin single-crystal diamond target (Radiator) where a small fraction of them radiate polarized high-energy gamma rays through a process known as coherent bremsstrahlung. After they radiate, the energy-degraded electrons are deflected by the magnetic field of the tagging spectrometer into an array of detectors known as tagging counters, while the rest of the beam electrons are directed to the beam dump. The radiated photons, meanwhile, continue to the right in the figure, and enter another hall where the liquid hydrogen target, surrounded by the main GlueX detector, is located.

The University of Connecticut group funded under this NSF grant has primary responsibility for several elements of this beam line, including the diamond radiators and the high-resolution tagging counters (tagger microscope). UConn graduate student Brendan Pratt was responsible for making the diamond radiators (see figure 2) which need to be very thin to avoid blowing up the electron beam as it passes through. They also need to be stiff enough to be self-supporting, and to shed the heat that builds up from the beam passing through them. Brendan achieved this by starting with a thick diamond block and milling out a thin membrane from the middle, which he was able to reduce to just 20 microns thickness while still maintaining the necessary flatness required to satisfy the precise beam-crystal alignment conditions for coherent bremsstrahlung. Ensuring that these conditions were met required that X-ray diffraction measurements be made on each crystal radiator after milling, which were carried out by the UConn group at the Canadian Light Source in Saskatoon, Saskatchewan. Figure 3 shows the diffraction results as a false-color image known as a rocking-curve topograph, in which extreme colors indicate regions of high stress. The uniform green color in the center shows that this diamond has a flat central zone that makes it suitable for use as a GlueX radiator. This diamond was first used for GlueX production in fall, 2018.

In other photon beam instrumentation, the UConn group also has primary responsibility for the tagger microscope detector (see figure 4). This detector was originally designed and built by the UConn group by graduate students James McIntyre and Alex Barnes, assisted by a team of more than 20 undergraduate students over a period of 3 years prior to 2016. During the period 2016-2018, the detector has been upgraded in two stages, the first in early 2017 and the second in early 2019, with the purpose of improving the tagger time resolution by increasing the light scintillation light yield. Following the upgrades, the tagger time resolution (see figure 5) is sufficient to give a clear separation between the individual pulses of the electron beam.

In addition to detector construction and commissioning support, UConn graduate students also each took on individual data analysis projects, extracting photoproduction cross sections from experimental data and interpreting the results in terms of polarization observables. Figure 6 shows one such result from the thesis of Brendan Pratt (PhD, April 2017) where he plots the angle between the beam polarization plane and the decay plane of the 𝝋(1020). The 𝝋(1020) is one of the well-known hadrons from previous experiments, which decays into a pair of other hadrons called kaons. The directions two decay kaons form a plane whose angle with respect to the polarization plane of the beam is expected to obey a cos(2𝟁) modulation with an amplitude proportional to the beam polarization. The 35% beam polarization that was expected under these conditions is confirmed by these results.

Within the period covered by this grant, the UConn group has produced 3 PhD’s, with a fourth expected within one year. Each of the three has been hired into a research position within a few months of graduation, two under the general title of Data Scientist in the private sector, and the third as a Staff Scientist at a national lab.
